title: 112_s431
content:
The Act is titled the "United States Marshals Service 225th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the United States Marshals Service. The United States Marshals, the first Federal law enforcement officers, were established under the Judiciary Act of September 24, 1789 by George Washington. He nominated the first 11 Marshals on September 24 and the remaining two on September 25, 1789, all confirmed by the Senate on September 26, 1789. The United States Marshals Service was created in 1969 by the Department of Justice and achieved Bureau status in 1974. Robert Forsyth, one of the original 13 Marshals, was the first civilian official of the US Government and the first Marshal to be killed in the line of duty. The United States Marshals Service Commemorative Coin will honor the oldest Federal law enforcement agency, the United States Marshals Service, by minting and issuing commemorative coins. The coin will bring attention to the agency's lasting legacy and proceeds from sales will support national museums and charitable organizations. The United States Marshals Service Commemorative Coin will have specific specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue commemorative coins in honor of the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service. This includes $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act for the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to specific specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins for the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to specific specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act for the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service will have designs emblematic of the achievements of the service. Each coin will include a value designation, mint date, years 1789 and 2014, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". Additional inscriptions may be determined appropriate by the Secretary. The $5 gold coins will feature the United States Marshals Service Star on the obverse and a design honoring fallen officers on the reverse. The $1 silver coins will have an image on the obverse. The $1 silver coins issued under this Act will bear an image emblematic of the United States Marshals' legendary status, depicting them as the lawmen of the frontiers with the motto "Justice, Integrity, Service". The half dollar clad coins will also have a specific design on the obverse. The dollar clad coins issued under this Act will bear an image emblematic of the United States Marshals Service and its history, while the reverse will depict the Marshals' role in pivotal social issues in American history, including the Whiskey Rebellion and slavery. The designs for coins issued under this Act will be selected based on realism, historical accuracy, and resemblance to artwork from the "Golden Age of Coinage" in the United States. Sculptors and artists like James Earle Fraser, Augustus Saint-Gaudens, and others will be involved in the design process. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Director of the United States Marshals Service and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in proof and uncirculated quality at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary can start issuing coins to the public from January 1, 2015, with a limited number reserved for the 225th Anniversary celebration. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2015.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act shall include a surcharge: $35 for the $5 gold coin, $10 for the $1 silver coin, and $3 for the half dollar coin. The surcharges received will be distributed to the U.S. Marshals Museum for preservation and maintenance of artifacts and documents. Under paragraph (1), thirty-three and one-third percent of surcharges from coin sales will be distributed to The National Center for Missing & Exploited Children, the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, and the Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association Foundation. All organizations receiving funds are subject to audit requirements. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. (d) Limitation.--No surcharge may be included with respect to the issuance of any coin under this Act during a calendar year if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for this provision.
